title: 105_hr2201
content: The Act titled "Lower East Side Tenement National Historic Site Act of 1997" is established for the purpose of preserving historical sites. Congress finds that immigration and cultural diversity are key factors in defining American identity, with the majority of citizens tracing their ancestry to immigrants. The late 19th and early 20th centuries saw a significant influx of immigrants to the United States, particularly to the Lower East Side neighborhood of Manhattan. The Lower East Side Tenement at 97 Orchard Street in New York City is a notable survivor of the humble buildings that housed immigrants during this period. The Lower East Side Tenement at 97 Orchard Street in New York City is a museum dedicated to interpreting immigrant life during the greatest wave of immigration in American history. It was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1994 and found suitable for inclusion in the National Park System. The purposes of the Act are to preserve and interpret the themes of immigration, tenement life, housing reform, and architecture in the United States. It also aims to continue interpreting the immigrant phenomenon in New York City's Lower East Side and enhance the interpretation of national monuments like Castle Clinton, Ellis Island, and the Statue of Liberty. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. Defines "historic site" as the Lower East Side Tenement at 97 Orchard Street in New York City and "Museum" as the nonprofit organization that owns and operates the tenement building. "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Lower East Side Tenement at 97 Orchard Street in New York City is designated as a national historic site and affiliated with the National Park System. The site's operation and interpretation will be coordinated with other historic sites related to the immigrant experience in the United States. The Lower East Side Tenement National Historic Site is owned and operated by the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, a nonprofit institution. The Lower East Side Tenement National Historic Site is managed by the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, a nonprofit institution. The Secretary can enter a cooperative agreement with the Lower East Side Tenement Museum for marking, interpretation, and preservation of the national historic site. Assistance in technical and financial aspects is authorized for preservation-related improvements. A management plan will be developed with the museum to define roles and responsibilities for interpretation and preservation. Interpretation and programming for the Lower East Side Tenement National Historic Site, Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, and Castle Clinton national monuments will be coordinated to enhance the stories at each site within 2 years. The Act does not authorize property acquisition at 97 Orchard Street or overall financial responsibility for the Lower East Side Tenement National Historic Site. SEC. 6. APPROPRIATIONS: Sums necessary for carrying out this Act will be appropriated.
